application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents
application.label: a91ee48

div.p: Round 6/Input (all) vs. Round 3/Input (all) Round 6/Input (m1) vs. Round 3/Input (m1)
Round 6/Input (all) vs. Round 6/Input (m1) Round 6/Input (all) vs. Round 6/Input (m2)

div.head: Last Wash Elution
div.p: Phage Titer (PFU / mL) 0.0e+00 5.0e+07 (a,b) In order to validate our phage display assay we employed two well-studied WW domain variants, W17F and W39F. Shown is quantitative Sanger sequencing data for two successive rounds of selection of each of these variants versus wild type WW domain on both control (dark gray bars) and PPYP ligand-containing (light gray bars) beads. The input phage stock contained an equal mixture of wild type and variant phage. Control beads (dark gray bars) showed no preference for either variant versus wild type. (c) Shown is quantitative Sanger sequencing of a control selection performed at the same time as the six round WW domain diversity library selection using identical beads and phage stocks. The input for this control selection at each round was an equal mixture of wild type and W39F. Thus, this control gives a measure of the relative strength of selection for each round. (d) Shown is the phage titer for the last wash and the elution after each round of selection of the WW domain diversity library.
Supplementary Figure 2. Overlapping Paired End Reads Reduce Average Error.

The running-median smoothed Phred-scaled per-base quality scores at each position are shown for the forward (gray line) and reverse (broken gray line) reads. Forward and reverse reads were combined, yielding a consensus sequence with a per-position error calculated as the sum of forward and reverse base quality scores for concordant base calls (i.e. error probabilities were assumed to be independent) or the highest quality score for discordant base calls. Blue dots represent the average combined score at each position and the red line indicates the running-median smoothed curve. Data presented corresponds to an analysis of reads from the input library. yap3 / yap0 ( ) Amino acid subsitution (or non-synonymous mutation) log 2 (Mutation frequency in selected/input) -4 -2

figure.figDesc: Supplementary Figure1. Titering and Sequencing of Phage Display of the WW Domain.

Supplementary Figure 3. Sequencing of the WW Domain Diversity Library Reveals the Expected Distribution of DNA Mutations. (a) Shown is a plot of the number of sequences with a given number of DNA mutations in the WW domain input library as determined by high-throughput sequencing. The observed distribution of mutations (light gray bars) closely matches the predicted distribution (dark gray bars). (b) The number of unique DNA sequences with a given number of mutations is plotted. Only one sequence, the wild type, has zero mutations. The observed distribution of mutations (light gray bars) closely matches the predicted distribution given the total number of sequences obtained (dark gray bars). (c) The number of unique DNA sequences with a given number of mutations is plotted. The observed distribution of mutations (light gray bars) is compared to the total number of possible sequences with a given number of mutations (dark gray bars). (d) A cumulative distribution of the number of times variants were sequenced is shown. The inset shows the cumulative distribution for variants sequenced up to 10 times. doi: 10.1038/nmeth.1492 Supplementary Figure 4. WW Domain Enrichment Ratio and Codon Adaptation Index are Uncorrelated.Codon adaptation index 1 scores were calculated using the CodonW algorithm for synonymous variants of the wildtype hYap65 WW domain that significantly enriched or depleted after six rounds of selection as determined by a Poisson-based test. For each variant, the codon adaptation index is plotted against the enrichment ratio.Behave Similarly Across Rounds of Selection and Mutational Distance. Mutational frequency (selected/input) is plotted for various subsets of data. (a, b) Mutational frequency is plotted using data from round six and data from round three (a) and for variants containing only single mutations (b). (c, d) Panel c shows round six enrichment ratios calculated using variants containing only one mutation versus enrichment ratios derived from all variants. Panel d shows round six enrichment ratios calculated using variants containing only two mutations versus enrichment ratios derived from all variants. Preferences by Position. Mutational preference by position is shown for round 3 versus input (a, c, e) and round six versus input (b, d, f). Panels a and b show amino acid scans for all data, c, d show single mutant data and e, f show double mutant data. Each panel of the plot corresponds to a different position within the WW domain, indicated by the orange bar in the header. The x-axis of each panel indicates substituted amino acid while the y-axis indicates log 2 (enrichment ratio). Blue dots indicate a measured enrichment ratio, red dots indicate the wild type sequence (which enriched 1.7-fold) and grey dots indicate mutations not observed.

P G WK R V S D -I A G -T Y Y WH I P T G T T Q WE R P L P A G WM R V Q D -T S G -T Y Y WH I P T G T T Q WE P G WE E R K D + P D G R + Y Y V N H N T K T T Q WE R P Supplementary Figure7. Sequence Alignment of 73 WW Domains.Residues 173-202 of the human Yap65 (Yap1) protein were aligned to the PFAM WW domain seed alignment (PF00397) using Jalview 2 . The hYAP65 WW domain sequence used in this study is boxed in red. Conserved positions are indicated with blue highlighting. Red highlighting indicates conservation of positively charged residues at position 35. The consensus sequence -built excluding the hYap65 sequence-is shown at the bottom, along with relative conservation at each position.

div.head: High-resolution mapping of protein sequence-function relationships
div.p: Binding energies were predicted for mutations occurring at positions that make significant contact with the ligand (Y28, L30, T37, and W39). Predicted binding energies relative to wild type are plotted against observed enrichment ratios. Dashed lines are arbitrarily placed to highlight variants with extreme negative enrichment ratios (2 -3.5 relative to wild type) or highly disruptive predicted binding energies (>2 Rosetta energy units relative to wild type). The difference in free energy of folding was predicted using the following command line:

fix_bb_monomer_ddg.linuxgccrelease -ddg::weight_file soft_rep_design -ddg::iterations 50 -ddg::local_opt_only falseddg::min_cst true -ddg::mean false -ddg::min trueddg::sc_min_only false -ddg::ramp_repulsive trueddg::minimization_scorefunction standard -ddg::minimization_patch score12

To run a single trajectory of the binding simulation, the RosettaScript shown below was used: In each case, the FASTA sequence of the WW variant was used to set the target_sequence option in the RosettaScript. RosettaScripts was invoked with the following command line:

Nature Methods: doi: 10.1038/nmeth.1492 Supplementary References Cited 1. Sharp, P. M. and Li, W. H., The codon Adaptation Index--a measure of directional synonymous codon usage bias, and its potential applications. Nucleic Acids Res. 15 (3), 1281Res. 15 (3), -1295Res. 15 (3), (1987)). 2. Waterhouse, A. M., Procter, J. B., Martin, D. M., Clamp, M., and Barton, G. J., Jalview Version 2--a multiple sequence alignment editor and analysis workbench. Bioinformatics 25 (9), 1189-1191 (2009).
